posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Right now, the plan is as follows:

1. California will restore natural watersheds. This will permit reconstruction of the natural ecology, which will reduce desertification and prevent dust formation. This will also kill much of the ranching within California, especially the onions grown for feed. Such a program is compatible with or without the proposed Delta Tunnels.

2. Washington will ration water to preserve Hoover Dam's functionality. HD will only be turned off as an absolute last resort as it will cause a huge power crisis since the mountain states have no gas pipelines. Agribusiness within Arizona and Nevada will then end. Western ranching dies here.

3. Water will be trucked in physically. Because of how IRL logistics works, communities around railroads will get better water access than those without. Just as in Mexico. States will give water priority to their largest cities (Reno, Las Vegas, Salt Lake City, Odgen, Phoenix, Yuma, Tuscon), counties will rate all their ZIP codes based on water network access, and individual towns will have to self-finance collective water delivery or force that cost onto individual homeowners. Once taps go dry Walmart will sell out within a day or two, by which point people stop bathing within their own homes. Slowly, everything will get dirty and stink.

4. Smaller communities will just die, just as they did a century ago with the original California Water Project. In Eastern CA and Central NV first the big (water-heavy) industrial complexes went, then the railroads, then the commercial businesses, then the residents. Rural farm communities will be hurt the hardest and most will depopulate to 0 as homes are re-tagged and people move to the big cities for work. Larger cities will have a larger tax base to finance collective water purchasing, and these will be the cheapest to live in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In short, the inland west's human geography will now have to match real geography again. Large cities will be located where washes and railroads congregate, and fed by them in the winter and summer respectively. Development from them will be based on railroads, as it was in the past. Suburban tract developments will slowly rot away and be outright abandoned as water rationing is instituted and their taps are shut off before others. The "shut off" itself doesn't necesarily have to be permanent either - again using Mexico as an example, certain districts will have their water shut off seasonally to preserve it for larger urban districts. Others will have the equivalent of a "brown out" and use dirtier non-potable water, but by this point people will tolerate it to wash with. Individual homes will be rated on their water factor and single family detached housing will be very unfavorable to large apartment complexes and condos that have collective water delivery paid by tenants' HOA fees. And with politics considered, the real estate companies that back these developments will collectively finance their own water delivery. And the company town is reborn.

This has been brewing for decades but only California and large cities (Reno, Vegas and Phoenix specifically) took action to deal with it. Utah will probably be hurt the hardest in the near term as they'll obtain dust bowl conditions, but Arizona faces a total population readjustment as Nevada did in the 70s.

posting the PDF here
>As part of the science goals for the planned Mars 2020 mission, two instruments, PIXL and
SHERLOC, intend to study the Mars surface at a close scale. These two instruments are
planned to be used on smooth rock surfaces that are free of dust and other particles. Such
surfaces are prepared by using a drill with an abrading drill bit; residual dust and particles
are then blown away using a compressed gas system—the Gas Dust Removal Tool (gDRT).
Early in the design process a risk of valve leakage below the vendor’s -20C rating was
identified. To mitigate this risk a parallel path was implemented: 1) qualify the valves to
operate at -135C, and 2) develop thermal control capability to elevated temperatures in case
qualification efforts are unsuccessful. While qualification efforts are ongoing, it is expected
that the valves will be qualified to an operating temperature of -135C. In the event that
qualification is not successful, thermal control has been realized via a thermally isolated valve
configuration and thermostatically controlled heaters. Thermal testing of gDRT has validated
this design and enabled thermal model correlation in order to provide more accurate survival
energy predictions. The resulting energy consumption for heating the valves at the Jezero
landing site represents a minimal impact to the Rover energy budget.

No.
The human brain is composed of about 10^26 particles and performs about 10^22 elementary operations per second for its function, and does so in a volume of about 1400cubic centimeters and about 20watts.
The law of conservation of information means that you can not simulate a system using less information than the system itself.
So there is no way for you to replicate your mind on some other substrate.

>>15064109
It's like the saying, you are the sum of the fife people closest to you. Same goes for the information you get. What is your input? What do you read, what do you watch?
If you're into maths or physics and have never read the words of the great mathematicians and physicists, then that's the mistake. And I don't talk about secondary and tertiary literature, I mean their original works. Have you read Euclid, have you read Euler, have you read Poincaré?
Same goes for every other field. Go to the source and get the knowledge without a filter. Try to cut out mediocre authors, just consume the brightest of old days and of today. They will inevitably influence you; even if you never get on their level, but even if you reach 5% of them you're already miles ahead of everyone else that learns from average people.

In whatever field you are, try to get the whole picture. You have to develop intuition for it, so that even if you see something new you already know the answer or at least know what you have to do. You have to gain complete mastery in a field, that will probably take you 10 years.

And then study another field as a hobby. But do it with the intention to gain deep understanding and recognize patterns. Maybe you will see connections between those fields, maybe you can create something completely new by connecting those fields.
For example, if you are a chemist and study computer science as a hobby, you could develop a software for chemist that could become the industry standard, because it's so much better than the alternatives. But there are so many ways to combine different fields. Don't give up, I believe in you.

Method for Induction of Frozen State of Water at Room Temperature Using Crystal-Derived Coulomb Lines in Support of Biologically Safe Suspended Animation

Efforts toward achieving the goal of safely suspending entropy in biological tissues have been largely stymied by two serious hurdles related to the methods being explored.

In cryogenic suspended animation, the first impasse is that water, when it transitions from a liquid state to a solid state, becomes jagged and expands, rupturing the cellular membranes of too many cells in the body for a human being to come back to life after being thawed.

Certain creatures such as frogs have chemicals in their bodies in abundance that act like antifreeze, preventing crystal formation. Thus far, no biologically safe chemical has been identified that could achieve for humans this effect.

Cryogenic preservation also has as a major disadvantage that a loss of coolant would result in the death of the person being preserved. Over stretches of decades or even hundreds of years, the number of ways in which something might go wrong outnumber the ways in which they might go right.

Fundamentally, a zero-energy, solid-state mechanism with no moving or electronic components would be needed that does not harm the living being undergoing the process of suspended animation.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
To understand how this may be achieved, one has to first understand how water takes on a frozen (i.e. lattice) configuration when its temperature drops below zero degrees Celsius. Water is frozen when its atoms arrange themselves in a lattice configuration. This happens because the thermal oscillations of the atoms are no longer sufficient at sub-zero temperatures to counteract the mutual repulsion of the negatively charged electrons of the H2O. These molecules constantly seek to maintain a maximal diffusive distance from one another. When electrons align, Coulomb forces are multiplied. As such, when water takes on a lattice configuration, the water can diffuse to a greater extent than otherwise possible if it were in a liquid state.

When water is above a certain temperature, individual molecules can move about randomly, breaking the ordered structure and rendering the overall body of molecules a liquid. Thus, two forms of motion; thermal motion and the Coulomb-enhanced diffusive motion are at odds with one another.

One of the key behaviors of freezing water that makes cryogenic preservation problematic is the expansion that occurs in the instant of the phase change. While it is generally true that liquids contract as their temperature decreases, the boundaries of phase changes of matter are an exception to this rule.

This brings us to the reason why room-temperature crystallization of water is the solution that will enable successful suspended animation. If it were possible to cause water to transition to a frozen state at room or body temperature or even higher temperatures, metabolic functions could be halted by bringing about a crystalline configuration of water within the body without any refrigeration or chemical injection.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
The key difference here is that since the water is at a comparatively high temperature to begin with; having not undergone the contraction associated with the drop from 36°C to 0°C; it would not expand harmfully when it enters the artificially-enhanced Coulomb-induced frozen state.

While Coulomb forces acting without the benefit of aligned electrons are understood to have the ability to extert force over a distance of about four atomic widths of hydrogen, when alignments exist, the field of influence can be expanded almost indefinitely. Crystals such as quartz have already been synthetically constructed in order to create these alignments to exert Coulomb force over great distances. If a sufficient number of these crystals could be aligned, force lines great enough to induce crystallization of water at high temperatures could be produced over an area large enough to "hot freeze" something the size of an adult human being.

Depending upon how large of a crystal would be needed to produce this effect, one of two primary approaches could be used. One would be a casket in which a crystalline lid is lowered onto the casket, sealing a person inside. If a thickness greater than a few feet is required, the entire wall of a building might be constructed out of the same type of crystal with the individual to be preserved being slid into position under the wall on a movable tray.

Since the freezing and thawing processes would, in theory, be instantaneous and would not result in the expansion of the frozen water, the person frozen should be able to arrive safely in the future in approximately the same state as when they entered the Coulomb field.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15064675
>How do you go from a protein to modifying the various slopes and curves that define 3-dimensional body parts
That's not how genes actually work even if it's a nice way of trying to intuit the process. There's no gene that says the beak has to curve 30 degrees per cm or what ever.

The easiest way to understand it is to imagine that you have 3 factors in place
stem cell -> specialized cell
growth hormone
signal hormone

You start out with a blob of stem cells that produce growth hormone which causes the whole mass to expand, then when some trigger is reached some cells specialize in something and start emitting signal hormones which cause other cells to specialize in different things based on concentration and hence proximity which ensures pieces are roughly in the right places, initial and spot mistakes get paved over with cell death as the blob grows. Once a certain bit is grown enough it's signal hormone output is big enough to stop the growth hormone production which locks in the shape and size. Of course that's also not how it actually works but with that frame work you can actually create a model for growth of say a beak, the shape and size are determined by different relations of the various hormones, for instance long and narrow beak could be made when the growth rams down slowly while a stubby beak could be made when the growth drops sharply in relations to how many beak cells there are.
You have bunch of genes that activate states for the cell to be in and then related genes that react to different positive and negative secretions of nearby cells and the various thresholds control the shape and size of the mass as a whole.

And yes it's weird messy ad-hoc nonsense

>>15065435
>Did anybody else get taught about the dog eating moldy bread?
Eating green moldy bread as a cure for "ailments" goes back thousands of years. People didn't know why it worked, just that it did help most ailments.

Germ-Theory still was not a thing.

Healers and witch doctors knew about the healing effects for as long as humans have been making breads, and the knowledge was often a guarded secret of theirs, as garlic/onions and herbs were, or boiling water.and clothing to prevent spread of parasites and disease.

In recent times, journals of mountain men and French trappers recall of eating molded bread for pnuemonia and other infections in the 1700s-1800s.

The Fleming story is the most common for our western culture, as it was documented and the documents saved and repeated and incorporated into student curriculum.

Just because someone "discovered" something that people knew for thousands of years, doesn't make it a great discovery. Same as a zoomer "discovering" something "new" that had gone out of style but was popular in their great-grandparent's days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15065250
>It has already been proven that if (n-1)! + 1 % n = 0, then n is prime.
That's one of the implication directions of Wilson's theorem, but the integer n must be greater than 1 (given that n = 1 works but is not a prime).
Your image -- if you fix the ln(p) mistake -- gives the reverse implication direction of Wilson's theorem. In other theorems, the biconditional doesn't hold, so always carefully distinguish between an implication and its converse.
>But factorial is too big to calculate on a computer because there's too much multiplication, so why don't people just use logarithm instead? If you calculate the log of all whole numbers from 1 to n, and sum them together, then you just have to raise the log "base" to that power, and the result will be equal to the factorial.
You can find plenty of cases in numerical analysis where log factorials are used instead of factorials, but if you're just going to reintroduce the factorial value anyway by raising e to the log factorial, what have you gained?

Think of it like this.

You have a square, which has 2 dimensions. You shine a light on its side, what is the shape of the shadow? A line, which has 1 dimension.

You have a cube, which has 3 dimensions. You shine a light on its side, what is the shape of the shadow? A square, which has 2 dimensions.

What would a shape with 4 dimensions be, which, if you shine a light on its side, has a cube as its shadow, which has 3 dimensions?

The answer is a hypercube.

Pic related to help you visualise how this works. If you can't see it then there's just no hope for you.

>>14938339
>Is there a definitive physics text for undergraduate calculus based physics 1 and 2?
No, they're all more or less the same. The standard in my state when I did my undergrad was Halliday, Resnik, and Krane. The standard at the school I'm teaching at is Serway. For better or worse every intro physics sequence follows basically the same pattern: Physics I - mechanics and thermo, Physics II - E&M and modern. And all the books go through basically the same structure and routine for introducing topics:
You start with kinematics because it's the basis for all the vector and calculus language you're going to be using for describing motion later on, then forces and the laws of motion as a setup for the rest of linear dynamics (work and energy, impulse and momentum, etc). Then rotational motion, equilibrium, and dynamics to gradually introduce and build up the background needed to describe and combine translation and rotation. Then fluids, thermo, waves, sound.

E&M starts out by introducing charge and Coulomb's Law, basic integration methods for Gauss's Law/Poisson's Equation, circuits, more circuits, magnetic fields, forces, and induction, Faraday and Ampere, really gross Biot-Savart Law integration, then EM waves, optics, and a smidge of modern stuff if there's time.

Some undergraduate courses do a four-course sequence where they split off all the thermal stuff into one semester and all the quantum/relativity stuff into another, but I think the most common practice now is to give thermal the short end of the stick and lump contemporary topics into a Physics III or a Modern Physics course.

tl;dr - Just pick whatever's cheapest or whatever you can pirate easiest.

>>15034298
No, it's actually a terrible list that will demotivate you. Several of the "prerequisite" books there are more advanced than the "final" calculus books.

If you're starting below a basic highschool level you will be much better off with a highschool level text, or something like khanacademy if you need immediate feedback drills. Look to see if any local schools run adult remedial classes if you're really serious. Especially when you're just starting out it's very useful to have access to an instructor.

If you can handle highschool algebra and geometry well enough, I like Epp's Discrete Mathematics for a gentle first introduction to more abstract "mathy" mathematics. It's very well presented and should be accessible to a motivated student, even if their background is a little weak.

I think it is a great path if you like to think mathematically but also want to pursue a high paying career.

I have a degree in maths (not quant maths) and I think if I had the choice nowadays, I’d still choose the general math degree because seeing all of math really helped me discover what I truly liked. But if you are someone who is set on going into a quant type job then yeah, you don’t need to know algebraic number theory. Go straight for the quant shit.

As a career it is very hit or miss. First, quant spots are top funds are insanely competitive. These are the jobs that every ivy league psycho apply to so you need to be at least as good as them. Beyond that, the job itself is very stressful. I did a summer internship in a quant role and even in that limited capacity I was already feeling the pressure. Nowadays I work in finance but not as a quant.

However, understanding markets and volatility is not just a quant’s game. For example, recently I’ve been interested in getting a risk manager position at a fund like Jane Street. You get paid a lot less than a quant (obviously) but this is more like a normal 9 to 5 job but in a place like Jane Street. However, there is competition even for that.

The nature of finance means that there will always a small amount of jobs. If you needed 1,000 people to manage 1M dollars then you would be losing money just paying salaries. The real math is more like 1 person for every 10 million you are managing as then salaries are a rounding error and you can focus on returns. But if you think you have what it takes, go for it.

posts.com: What's /sci/'s opinion on philosophy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Philosophy is for fleshing out consistency, but is incomplete for finding truth.

Philosophy does not provide additional knowledge, it only helps bring flesh out assumptions that already exist. This is why philosophies about morality or the proof of God's existence are always going to fail.

We base our philosophies on assumptions that we already hold, and cannot discern truth until we compare it to external data. But to reach a conclusion like, "This is morally right" requires the moral rightness to be implicit in the assumptions.

The same with proving God's existence. The only way to prove it with certainty is to assume his existence, and so without some sort of external verification, it becomes pointless.

In general, I think philosophy is best at the armchair level. Great for talking with friends, and challenging assumptions, but it our assumptions are deeply ingrained and only will change with experience.

>>15049605
There's a huge difference between being interested in ethics from a cold, theoretical perspective, and wanting to be a good person. Ethicists tend to either assume that all people ought to act the same way or that all humans are actually good and seek for virtue and moderation. They more often than not imagine themselves to be at the helm of society, telling people how to act, what to do, in what way to live. They tuck it all away under assumptions of a priori rationality or innate instinct, making no effort to consider the possibility that individuals have their own preferences and criteria for what might be good or pleasant. They more often than not reduce all ethical choices to either an optimum state possessing certain qualities or the least harmful outcome, as if all choices could be split up that way.
In real life, ethicists like Jean Jacques Rousseau and Arthur Schopenhauer tend to have misanthropic tendencies, hating their fellow man and believing themselves to be at the heart of a conspiracy to bring them to ruin. They have a deep feeling of love of this poetic image of Man they conjure themselves, but they hate their mothers, their neighbors, their "friends", and everyone else whom they come across.

There are plenty of physical reasons to consider GR as incomplete. On one side of the Einstein field equations, you have a stress energy tensor which corresponds to the energy of things like light (photons), ordinary matter, etc. That part of the equation is known to be quantum mechanical, so the other side of the Einstein equation (the spacetime geometry side) can't completely ignore quantum effects and only works when the quantum effects of the light, matter, etc. can be ignored, which is the case for most of cosmology. >>15049451
Philosophy is the set of general principles that are necessary in order to form hypotheses, i.e. the use of logical inferences, observation, and the use of language to ask questions. These are necessary skills for conceptual analysis and the synthesis of knowledge. It is the general blueprint, or system of rational cognition that is then filled in by the physical and empirical sciences. That is why fields like epistemology, logic and metaphysics have arisen from doing philosophy. Knowledge and reality itself have to be clarified and investigated from a general point of view if we want to fill in our system of knowledge with greater certainty. Physics and biology can then be placed on a strong foundation within a system of knowledge.

Because Mathematics can be reduced to logic, Maths is the language of our arguments about things that are. Math does not tell us anything about the world, but rather allows us to describe hypotheses about the world in a language. But the ontological status of abstract entities in Maths becomes another problem for philosophy.

Posting pictures of muscly men does not add to the substance of your argument. On the contrary, you should know that there is nothing to be gained in the strength of an argument by appealing to either famous writers (which is, as you should know, an "argumentum ab auctoritate") or to aesthetic concerns.
Either something is by itself true and recognizable as such by the means of observation subjected to the highest level of logical scrutiny or it is merely hogwash promoted simply due to socio-culturally influenced personal preferences.
Plato is one of the people whom the Western philosophical tradition started with, but you will hardly find anyone who will call themselves an orthodox Platonist, or a true believer in the theories of metempsychosis or anything of that sort even in Continental philosophy departments which have a high focus on philology and the Classics. Plato is just one thinker among many in the Western tradition, just like Aristotle, Berkeley, Hume, Smith, Schopenhauer, Husserl, Derrida, etc. Aristotle's rules of inference are just about the only stuff that no person, be it a philosopher, a lawyer, or a mathematician, or a physicist, would ever dare to dispute from his work. Everything else is subject to doubt.
The scientific method itself has undergone many reforms, with people shifting in paradigms throughout the ages from rationalism to empiricism, then over to compromises between the two advocating for the primacy of rational arguments backed by extensive amounts of empirical evidence to others giving priority to great masses of empirical evidence, with all models merely being guesses at best and lies at worst.
Over time, there have been changes in morality, in beliefs regarding human regards, regarding how power structures ought to exist, what kind of people ought to be in command, whether all people deserve to be treated as equals, etc., and none of it is necessarily "truer" than other beliefs.

>So, does the fact that you can apply the scientific method to religious claims mean that science 'allows in' religion or necessarily 'admits' or affirms anything about religion
In science, the (tentative) truth of a claim is decided based on experimental verification. So science can take a claim made by a religious person and either conclusively debunk it or tentatively confirm it using experimentation. It never decides the truth of the statement based on whether or not the person says he received it from god or whether or not the person is a religious figure.

You, and the author of that paper for high schoolers, claim that science is just one epistemological approach out of several. However, regarding learning truths about the real world, it is the only one which has ever worked so in calling it "just one approach", you are explicitly rejecting all evidence and that is an antiscientific position.

>>15058659
>There were no matematicians then only people thinking about interesting questions and trying to solve interesting problems
Absolute retardation. Aristotle explains in thorough detail the distinction between physics, mathematics, and the philosophy of first principles (called theology in his day, and metaphysics or ontology in our days) in part 1 of book VI of his Metaphysics. Even back in those days, there were some people who were interested only in mathematical or geometrical knowledge, some who were interested in physical phenomena, some who were interested in the natural sciences, and some who were interested in purely theoretical treatments of the first, most abstract essences of things, such as logic and metaphysics. Some people were interested in astronomy without ever bringing up topics like Being or the Gods, and some were interested in the discussion of virtue and ethics without ever giving even a single thought to problems of area, fitting, quadrature, or any other issue dealt with by geometers of the day. Even though all of these areas of interest were "epistemai" ("knowledges"), they were not all disciplines that followed one same set of analytic procedures and methods of discovery. Just as Homer was no expert in the art of warfare or the art of navigation despite having composed many lines of his poems in reference to them, then so were Plato and Aristotle not mathematicians despite having mentioned mathematical arguments that were commonplace knowledge in their times in their own works.
For if medics are known to have existed, as seen from the cult of Asclepius, well before the birth of Thales of Miletus, then so may we assume that every single arithmetic reckoning and estimation done that may be found in ancient Babylonian clay tablets and Egyptian papyri were not a product of philosophical enquiry starting from first principles, but rather grappling with numbers for the sake of finding magnitudes of use for solving specific problems.

Art has always been fairly straightforward. It's just an expression of what you see in your mind's eye onto some medium.

Working memory is important stuff for learning and also just general intelligence. It’s not too hard to see why working memory could be so important. Working memory boils down to ‘how much stuff you can think about at the same time’.Imagine a poor programmer who has suffered brain damage and has only enough working memory for 1 definition at a time. How could he write anything? To write a correct program, he needs to know simultaneously 2 things - what a variable, say, contains, and what is valid input for a program. But unfortunately, our programmer can know that the variable foo contains a string with the input, or he can know that the function processInput uses a string, but he can’t remember these 2 things simultaneously! He will deadlock forever, unsure either what to do with this foo, or unsure what exactly processInput was supposed to work on.

>>15064942

The signals that travel through your brain aren’t electrical, they’re electrochemical, and man, are they slow. Slow as molasses in zero G. Slow as a snail on quaaludes.

Researchers have measured the speed of those signals in neurons. Different neurons transmit impulses at different speeds—the C fibers that conduct pain impulses are particularly slow—but fast neurons only schlep signals around at about 100 meters per second.

The speed of light, just for comparison, is roughly 3,000,000 times faster. Or to put it another way, the signals in your brain move at somewhere in the neighborhood of 1/3,000,000th, or 0.0000033%, of the speed of light.

Not only are neural signals slower than light, they’re slower than sound. They’re slower than slow subsonic bullets.

Math hack is any trick to solving a problem which reduces a problem in such a way that it feels unreal, like trivialising a very difficult problem or using something from an entirely different field.
I'll start: the [math] \textit {probabilistic method.} [/math] It satisfies both criteria.

>Show that: in a circle with 2/3rd circumference red and the rest blue, there is a way to inscribe a square such that at least 3 of its vertices are red.

[math] \textit {Solution} [/math]

Let [math] \forall \; i \in \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4 \} \; V_i : \Omega \to \{ 0 , 1 \} [/math] be a random variable such that [math] V_i ( \omega ) = 1 [/math] iff [math] \omega [/math] is the event that a uniform random inscribed square has its [math] i [/math]-th vertex red. Let [math] \omega_i [/math] be the even that the [math] i [/math]-th vertex is red. Then [math] \mathbb E [V_i] = \mathrm P ( \omega_i ) = 2/3 [/math]. Let [math] X : \Omega \to \{ 0, 1 , 2, 3, 4 \} [/math] be the random variable that denotes the number of vertices that are red of a uniform random inscribed square. Then:
[eqn] X = \sum_{i=1}^4 V_i \implies \mathbb E [X] = \sum_{i=1}^4 \mathbb E [V_i] = 8/3 [/eqn]
Since [math] \operatorname{ceil} \mathbb E [X] = 3 [/math], there must be some square whose number of red vertices is at least 3, otherwise the expected value can be no greater than 2. QED. Linearity of expectation despite dependence is a pretty neat math hack in itself.

Constructivists need not reply.

>>15060167
Imagine a colored pen at each vertex of the square. Each pen can be toggled red or blue. Now rotate the square about its center. To ensure that 3 red vertices are never possible, at least two of those pens must be blue at any moment. You need only turn 90 degrees total due to symmetry of the square. In that rotation, you will create at least 180 degrees of blue arc.

That is, 120 degrees of blue arc isn't enough to prevent 3 red vertices.

The proof is trivial. If you inscribe a regular polygon with n sides inside a circle, the angular distance between the first corner and the k'th corner is (k-1)*2*pi / n. For a square, this means that the angular distance between the first corner, and the 3rd/4th corners, is pi/2 and 3pi/2, respectively. Therefore, any arc that is >= 1/2 and < 3/4 of the circumference can be drawn in such a way that it three corners.

>>15062679
There are a few things that may indicate that a piece of text was generated using chatGPT or a similar language model:
>repetition or redundancy: chatGPT is trained on large amounts of text data, so it may generate text that includes repeated phrases or ideas.
>lack of context or coherence: chatGPT may generate text that does not make sense in the context of the conversation or that jumps between unrelated topics.
>unnatural or stilted language: chatGPT may generate text that does not sound natural or that includes unusual phrases or sentence structures.
>lack of personalization: chatGPT does not have access to personal information, so it may generate text that does not refer to the user by name or that does not take into account the user's previous comments or questions.
It's worth noting that chatGPT is just one example of a language model, and other models may exhibit different characteristics. Additionally, as language models continue to improve, it may become increasingly difficult to identify whether a piece of text was generated by a machine or written by a human.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I literally dropped a 2.5 hr documentary about this a few days ago

https://youtu.be/wD4xrnzKN1Y

In short, he was definitely smart, but his math was not genius tier. It was kind of standard measure theory / analysis. Many of his proofs were waaay too detailed for no reason (he wrote an alternate proof for a result his professors had proved 6 years earlier. Their proof was half a page. His was 8 pages for no reason other than he loved being detailed.) At the same time he was able to get some new results specifically because he was comfortable going so far in the weeds (e.x. That every F_sigma_delta set is the set of curvilinear convergence for some continuous half plane function).

Complex analysts were somewhat interested in his work at the time, but Ted had no interest in doing anything other than boundary functions. He was kind of a one trick pony, likely because he was sick of math by the time he left Berkeley, but his contributions at the end of the day were minimal because he didn’t make connections with the rest of the community. His field of boundary functions basically disappeared in the 70s after he left.

(3) He literally said he studied pure math because he wanted his work to be as inconsequential to industrial society as possible

It was actually the ancient Greeks who believed in the fundamental, particle description of the universe. The Greek word atom, for atomic, literally means indivisible. Eventually it was physicists and chemists who discovered this description as incorrect, that there is a substructure to the once thought indivisible particles ("atoms").

The atomic nature of the universe was consistently cut down, first with the discovery of the electron, and then with the nucleus containing protons and neutrons. Almost by sheer accident, when colliding electrons into protons, physicists discovered the electron was probing into the proton and scattering off constituents.

The mathematical description of these constituents is that of a field theory, and not actually particles. Ontologically if you think a discrete excitation of a field constitutes a particle, you expose your ignorance. You should thank the physicists for disabusing humanity from the particle description of the universe. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15059042
just study functions and how to do algebra on them. Like properties of log, ln, e^x, a^x, sinx, cosx, tanx. And study the unit circle and study basic properties of sin and cos.

I never took any precalculus/trigonometry course in my life. Turns out the above mentioned was all that was needed.

For example, suppose the fundamental equation sin^2(x) + cos^2(x) = 1. Turns out you can derive most of the other identities needed for calculus from that one. Like if you want the formula for sin^2(x) = 1 - cos^2(x) then subtract the cosine part from both sides. Similarly, try dividing through by cos^2(x) and you see that you get tan^2(x) + 1 = sec^2(x). similarly if you divide through by sin^2(x) you get 1+cot^2(x) = csc^2(x).

Now you wont need much more than that regarding trig identities. Now for trigonometry more broadly. Again I never learned it but what i did learn is that I can construct triangles such that I can use SOH CAH TOA that give me the values i need for angles I need. By exploiting that cos is even and sin is odd. i.e. cos(-x) = cos(x) and sin(-x) = -sinx.

So figure out some triangles so that theyre 1) a 30,60,90, and 2) 45,45,90. Then take the formula to convert between degrees and radians and verify that 30 = pi/6, 60 = pi/3, 90 = pi/2, 45 = pi/4. And then use SOH CAH TOA to make cos,sin of those angles in radians. And then use even and oddness of cos and sin to add/subtract multiplies of pi radians to those basic angles, and figure out how to fill in the rest of the unit circle.

You only need to do this stuff to a basic degree so that you can evaluate limits, derivatives, and integrals. you dont need the stuff to actually "do calculus"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15063773
You're shelving books at the library. If you don't care where they go, you can shelve books at a fast rate, but it will be difficult to find them later.

If you instead index each one properly, finding them again will be quick. But the amount of books you can shelve per hour will be much less.

So there's a trade off: do you want to absorb new experiences quickly, or access the memories of experiences quickly? Ideally, you want both. Sleep is a reindexing of sorts, organizing and establishing better connections between absorbed information. So the information you gather quickly while awake can be rearranged for better retrieval.

Is there any evidence for this? Hell if I know.
